blogPosts.content: import Figure from '../src/components/figure'; import SEO from '../src/components/seo'; import Reminder from '../src/components/reminder'; *This post is a (hopefully quick) guide on the most important equations for computing free space propagation of a wavefront in the Fresnel regime, and how to do it properly.* ### Helmholtz equation and elementary waves First, some background. Consider a monochromatic wave $\psi$ in vacuum. It is governed by Helmholtz equation: $$ \nabla^2\psi + k^2 \psi = 0 $$ The solutions to this equation are called elementary waves, which can either be - Plane waves: $$ \psi(\mathbf{r}) = A \exp{(-j \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r})} = A \exp{[-j (k_x x + k_y y + k_z z)]} $$ - or Spherical waves $$ \psi(\mathbf{r}) = \frac{A}{r} \exp{(-j k r)} $$ The names indicate that the wavefronts (i.e. the surfaces of constant phase) are either planes or spheres. In practice, we encounter waves that are way more complex than elementary waves. Fortunately, we can make things easier by what is called the **Angular Spectrum** of waves. ### Angular Spectrum Method (ASM) An arbitrary wavefront $\psi_1(x,y)$ can be decomposed into plane wave components using the Fourier transform (FT): $$ \psi(x_1,y_1) = \frac{1}{2 \pi} \iint \hat{\psi}(k_x,k_y) \exp{[-j (k_x x + k_y y)]} dk_x dk_y $$ that is, the wavefront is composed by a sum of plane waves of phase $\exp{[-j (k_x x + k_y y)]}$ each with amplitude $\hat{\psi}_1(x,y)$. Any wavefront can be decomposed in such fashion, including a spherical wavefront. That is the magic of the Fourier Transform at play. Now, how can one obtain the wavefront at a different plane $(x_2,y_2,z)$ in space? Well, instead of working with $\psi_1(x,y)$, one can propagate each plane wave component separately and then sum the contribution of all these elementary waves at $z$. This is done using the free space propagator $H(k_x,k_y)=\exp{(j z \sqrt{k^2 - k_x^2 - k_ y^2})}$, such that $$ \psi(x_2,y_2,z) = \frac{1}{2 \pi} \iint \underbrace{\hat{\psi}_1(k_x,k_y) \exp{(j z \sqrt{k^2 - k_x^2 - k_ y^2}})}_{\text{free space propagator multiplies each component}} \exp{[-j (k_x x + k_y y)]}dk_x dk_y $$ The can be expressed in operator form as $$ \psi(x_2,y_2,z) = \mathcal{F}^{-1}{ \mathcal{F}{\psi(x_1,y_1)} H(k_x,k_y) } $$ The above expression arise directly from the *Raleigh-Sommerfeld* diffraction solution (see reference [4] for a more detailed explanation). The only assumption here is that the distance between source and observation points be $>> \lambda$. ### Important approximations We can apply some approximations to get simpler forms of the propagator equations. For that, we make use of the **paraxial approximation**. One typically hears that this approximation means that the wave makes small amgles with the optical axes. Since the wave in principle spreads through all space and has plave wave components going in all directions, perhaps a more correct way of saying this is: the non-negligible plane wave components of the wavefront make a small angle with the optical axis [2]. One can think of a paraxial wave as one which varies much more in the trasversal $x,y$ plane than in the longitudinal $z$ direction. Paraxial waves are said to obey the **paraxial Helmholtz equation**, which has two important solutions: - Paraboloidal wave The paraboloidal wave is the paraxial approximation to the spherical wave. In this case, the $$ \psi(x_2,y_2) = \frac{e^{ikL}}{i \lambda L} \iint_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \psi(x_1,y_1) e^{ \frac{i k}{2 L}\left[{(x_2-x_1)^2+(y_2-y_1)^2} \right]} dx_1 dy_1 $$
